It reminds me of wonton dumplings but without the broth. I highly recommend those dishes at Red Tavern. The rabbit stew wasn't really a stew as it was more like a stewed rabbit entree. If you're a fan of Russian food or have never tried Russian food, I do recommend this place. Portions are huge and if you're coming here with a party of three, order 2 entrees and 1-2 appetizers and you should be set.
author: Danster L.

description:
Been here a 3 or 4 times.  Each time there was only 1 or 2 tables taken in the whole restaurant, but for some reason it seemed like the waiter/waitress was always busy in the back (they might not have enough cooks in the back?).

I always come for the stuffed cabbage, it reminds me of home :)
author: Mike Q.

description:
This is the best place to go for a Russian dinner in San Francisco (except, of course, if you know someone who does some mean home cooking).  They have all sorts of appetizers, ranging from salads to pelmeni to tongue to crepes with smoked fish and red caviar.  The main courses are also diverse and delicious.  

It ain't cheap, mostly because you'll want to try everything. It's a great place to come with a group.  Dessert is delicious also (napoleon cake!) and they have a great dessert wine called Nalivka.  It's hard to have just one.
author: Masha B.

description: Been meaning to come here since the previous incarnation. So happy we finally made it. This place will be heaven if you were raised by family from the part of the world where this cuisine originates. We ordered the borsch (always gotta try this), summer salad (love the excessive dill-- and would expect nothing less), baltic herring (oh yeah, full on), zucchini pancakes (good, but not our fav), beef tongue (fantastic dish), and the beef Stroganoff (best one I've ever had) with garlic potatoes. Pitcher of Czech beer and some phenomenal bread for dipping. I can't wait to come back here. Parking was easy on a Thursday night, a rarity on the weekends.
author: Brian J.

description:
I made a reservation in advance for my fam, about 20.  This restaurant has an arrangement  (no-brainer for me) of a different type of delicious dishes like salads, cold cuts, crepes rolled with meat, and more authentic food...., then the main course and desert w coffee/tea. It was great in every way. Service was prompt, especially that everyone was quite hungry :) Reasonably priced also.
Will be back
author: Amir K.

description: Russian food was fantastic, service is great and the decor is comforting. I will definitely come back and recommend this to anyone that will want to try a different cuisine. :)
author: Karina C.

description:
So this is my first and only experience with Russian/Eastern European food. But I loved everything I tasted. 

The first visit, my friends (no pictures sad face) had the bitcochek, the fire-grilled chicken (can't remember that proper name) and the rabbit stew while I feasted on their chicken a la tapers, a garlic marinated and (pressed) roasted Cornish game hen. The first time we weren't asked about sides so they all came out with the tavern potatoes. I tried everything and was amazed at how moist and just packed with flavor everything was. The pork was juicy, the fire grilled chicken was like BAM! and my garlic Cornish game hen had the best crisped skin while still keeping moisture and not being so dried out like typical chicken. The rabbit stew was out of this world, but it is rich and there were lots of bones so beware. 
We all couldn't stop raving about the freaking potatoes, I mean how do they do such magic to something so simple as potatoes. Moist and soft and fluffy, yet crispy too. ALIENS! Ha

The second visit I brought two new guests, they ended up both getting the cabbage rolls as they had had Russian style cabbage rolls in the past and loved them, while I picked out the bitcochek (marinated, breaded and fried pork loin). To be honest, I wasn't as wowed with mine as I was with my friend's the first visit , but it was still very moist and flavorful, but this time I felt I could taste the grease more I guess. The cabbage rolls came out in a sauce which my companions had said they weren't expecting but let me tell you, did in no way distract from the flavor. We also mixed up the sides this time, I tried the garlic potatoes, almost scalloped with a creamy garlic sauce, I wasn't much of a fan though. And we did the fried cauliflower, which I really liked. Along with the standard tavern potatoes. 

I did try the Russian root beer which is kvas, which reminded me of kombucha, a fermented tea thing, normally I would have drank it and I tried it a couple times but I'm immune compromised now and realized that probably wasn't te smartest since I didn't know much about how sanitary it is. 

We also got this appetizer called the Mushroom Julienne Cocotte ($7.50) which was mushrooms and chicken baked in 3 cheese blend. The size was kind of humorous but we all agreed we would eat the crap out of it, they need a bigger portion. 
 

The rabbit stew was the most expensive at around $21.95 or so, while the rest were between $14.95-$16. We felt a great value for the flavor. The service is cold and distant, like I would expect I guess, so don't expect smiles or friendliness or a loud voice. I didn't hear half of what the server asked haha
author: Tabitha E.

description:
Best Russian food in the city, hands down. Coming from Eastern Europe, I know how Russian food should taste, and Red Tavern's food is the most authentic Russian food I've had in North America. 
Borscht is delicious, just like my grandma makes! Beef tongue is a must try if you are feeling adventures. Julienne is great as well. 
All the staff speaks Russian, and it seems like a lot of Russians are coming to this place, and that's when you know that the food is actually good!
author: Luba Y.

description: Food didn't wow us.  Service was cold, unfriendly and slow.  And the weirdest thing is the music kept stopping then restarting with a new song for the 2 hours we were there.  It was disturbing!  A couple seated at the same time left 45 minutes before us because they were fortunate to have a faster waitress.  Food was just ok.  Not enough for me to visit again.
author: A. C.

description: I really enjoyed this place. I went with a group of six and we ordered a ton of items to share. We had borsch, olivie, potato zrazy, bread, veal pelmeny, some great fried cauliflower, and the meat platter. We also had Baltika imperial stout. To finish it off we split some napoleon cakes and blinis. Everything was quite tasty. If you're looking for something that you wouldn't normally have outside of a Russian restaurant, the olivie or pelmeny might be a good choice. The deserts were a bit pricey, but the napoleon cake was a delicious ending to the meal.
author: Jared R.

description:
Great food and even better service!
We have visited the place twice and both times had a great meal. 
Highly recommend the blini and the Napoleon cake.
author: Alex N.

description:
Get the borsch. You won't be disappointed. It's hearty, but doesn't make you feel stuffed afterword. It's the perfect dish for a cool San Francisco day, and the folks at Red Tavern have it nailed. 
Everything else we have ordered has been excellent as well. The service is great, and restaurant is clean and uncluttered. 
If you're in Little Russia in SF, I highly recommend stopping by Red Tavern.
author: Michael H.

description:
This is one of the best restaurants in SF!  I've been here 3 times.  Twice for my birthday with a large group and once for regular dinner.  I've been to many Russian restaurants (mostly in NY) and have to say the food here is spectacular.  It's like home cooking elevated to a higher level.  The ingredients are very fresh.  Everything is perfectly cooked and seasoned.  You can't go wrong.  I even approve of the borscht, which is frequently too sweet in other restaurants.  The ambiance is nice.  Service is good, but better if you're a Russian speaker (or have one in your group).  They have a beer and wine license, so if you bring your own vodka they will pour it into an unmarked container and provide you with shot glasses.  

PS.  Yes I am Russian and have brought my non-Russian friends who have all been shocked and amazed at the tastiness of my peoples' cuisine.
author: Mary V.

description: Food is ok but nothing spectacular. Very small portions but very over-priced! The worst thing was that the restaurant was very cold inside (maybe we South European have different sense of room's warmth). When I asked the waitress if they had a heating, she just said: "No, we don't", without any need to apologize or offer some solution. It's crazy! Most of staff is not very friendly and not particularly kind. I got cold from being in that cold room and I hated my experience from the Red Tavern. The only positive thing was my friend I met after years.
author: Milenko P.

description:
I bit over a year ago, I went here with all intentions of trying the place because it is in my neighborhood and it has great reviews. 

Through OpenTable, I was able to book a reservation for me and my boyfriend (at the time) really easily; however, I found out once we arrived that they were fully booked and they said they canceled my reservation right away (5-10 minutes later). Um, hello!! Not everyone has their OpenTable notifications and/or emails linked to their phones, so a phone call saying you canceled my booking would have been nice. 

Also, if the place is fully booked, make sure people can't make reservations on the server you are using!! For this alone, my review is not a happy one as I was rather disappointed with their level of service. 

Today, I walked in with my friend for lunch. We stood by the door next to the wait to be seated sign, and no one even greeted us despite the fact that staff continued to walk in and out of the back (some even right pass us to go in/out of restaurant). After quite a while, we were seated and began to look over the menu. It takes a while for the food to come out, but we assumed it was made fresh - over salted in my opinion but that may be how the Russian cuisine is compared to what I am used to. 

The bit that irked me and my friend was that the kind server suggested/asked if we would like bread, which we opt for. What we weren't told, was that there was a charge for this - most places we've been to that ask "would you like to try our bread" usually mean it's on the house but we want to see if you want the extra carbs. 

Anyway, overall, I don't think I would go here again. The food was good but too salty for me, while their service could use a bit of work.
author: Christina L.

description:
I am of Russian origin and this is one of the best Russian food venues I have been to in the US. The beauty of the menu is that it has the old time favorites with a modern twist. 

About the food - everything I have tried has been very fresh, with delicate flavors which are not overpowering and certainly none of that grease from a village restaurant in Russia. It seems that the owners take pride in the ingredients they use just like I do at home, so the flavors are quite similar to my own cooking. 

Certainly a go-to place when I am in the city and don't feel like cooking. Some of my favorites are the blini platter with smoked fish and salmon roe, beef stronganoff, lula kebob, pan fried potatoes with garlic and dill are to die for! And of course the dumplings with sour cherry. Although they have a separate dessert menu, I prefer this dish for dessert with it's sweet/tart flavor. They also have an incredible selection of european draft beer and some really nice georgian wines (they have a bit of sweetness to them, similar to red zin, so likely not to be enjoyed by strict pinot or cab lovers).

Last, but not least, I enjoy the fact that tablecloths are real, not paper and the place is very clean and comfortable. It is a very versatile venue that can be formal or casual, depending on your mood.

Definitely a good choice, especially with how reasonably it is priced (on average $6-10 appetizers and $15-25 entrees) 

Side note: In reading some of the other reviews I found that people are generally disappointed with the service. From my perspective - the waiters here are trained to serve, not socialize. They don't take extra time to make suggestions or check on how you are doing multiple times throughout your meal but they bring your food, clear the dirty plates and glance at you from the corner of the restaurant to see if you need their attention. I did not by any means find them to be rude and if they appear this way, it is probably something that is lost in translation. If you need them, just make eye contact and raise your index finger - they will get the message and come over!
author: Victoria G.

description:
5/9/13 Dinner

A bit of a culture shock here. I was the only non-white, non-Russian speaking patron here for dinner. Red Tavern is nestled in a block full of Asian restaurants in the Outer Richmond. A rather quiet restaurant with a somewhat romantic decor. Only one party of two were dining when we arrived for our 7pm reservation.

We knew we were in for a hearty meal so we didn't order too much food. So many things I wanted to try on the menu but ended up with:

*Borsch: how can you not try borsch in a Russian restaurant? Flavor is not as strong as I anticipated, and could be thicker. Cabbage very well cooked with a piece of beef cheek.

*Beef Stroganoff ($18.75):  sautéed pieces of filet mignon with mushroom served in a sauce made of sour creme in a puff pastry. I could smell the dish as soon as the pasty is cut open revealing the piping hot beef. 

*Beef Cheeks Stew ($18.75): Okay. Americans would consider beef cheek a cheaper cut of meat, but to us Asians and the Russians, this is delicacy. Cut in cubes and textured like bavette steak, it's slow-cooked until beef is so tender that melts in my mouth. Flavor is very strong, hinting herbs and wine. It's served in a metal bucket with a lid.

Each main course is allowed a side dish, which is predominantly potato. The beef cheek stew is served on a bed of potatoes. I should have picked fried cauliflowers.

The dining experience is good, although service can be slow (one server). Toward the end of our meal in walked a big party of 12, all speaking Russian. I can tell this restaurant is legit consider the exclusive patrons. I would definitely return to try the pelmeni (dumplings), the cabbage wrap, and the potato vareniki.
author: Matt Y.

description: Great great food!! First time trying Russian food and I'll definitely be back for some more
author: Charmz B.

description:
Zuckini thing, pelmeni and napoleon cake are must try. I'm pretty sure anything else on the menu is also very delicious. They do speak Russian. 
Not expensive at all. I just wish it was closer to downtown.
author: Egor H.

description: The best Russian restaurant in the area. They also do amazing catering. Very delicious dishes and high quality service.
author: Vladimir K.

description:
Service is usually good, but sometimes sucks- not consistent. What is consistent, is the quality of food. It is very good!!!
The place is small and is usually closed for banquets, reservations are recommended. We usually catch a table during off peak times or right after they open on Sunday.   , thank you!
author: Natalia A.

description:
I've been called and mistaken for a lot of ethnicities.

Filipino. Chinese. Korean. Vietnamese. Japanese. Hawaiian. Oriental (I'm not a freaking rug or vase OK!). Half Caucasian/half of all the aforementioned. 

One time I was at my friend's house and her brother was having a party with 20+ dudes. One asked me, "Are you Russian?" to which I responded, "Dude, do I look like Olga?!?!?" WTF. No offense to the Olgas out there. 

That was my only experience with Russian culture (not really an "experience" though), other than eating Pirozhkis at my high school beanery. Talk about needing to be cultured. 

Enter Red Tavern. 

Quietly opening in July 2011, Red Tavern took over Sadko which was also a Russian restaurant in San Francisco's Little Russia area (Outer Richmond). Finding street parking is a biatch in the area but there's a parking lot across Red Tavern that charges $3 for every 30 minutes. 

Combing through all the reviews, I was a bit scared before coming to Red Tavern. One star reviews mentioned being yelled at and being refused service. None of my Yelp friends had reviewed the place which made me even warier. I don't doubt the one star reviews. Service was as scary (in the beginning) as when I did something naughty as a child and had to face the wrath of my Chinese pitbull mom. *Hides in the corner* There's only one waiter and he is cold and brusque as can be which means I had to be on my very best behavior aka NO alkie for Cherylynn. BOO! At the end, he did warm up when I tried to make small talk with him so it's really just a cultural thing so don't take offense (just like rude service at Chinese restaurants). 

Do note that service is S-L-O-W. Don't come during peak dining hours or you'll be doing a lot of waiting. It took us 25 minutes just to pay the check and our reservations were at 5:30 PM. Yah, we eat dinner like old farts.

Oh, and don't be surprised when you walk in to have ALL eyes staring at you. A-W-K-W-A-R-D. We were the only Asian people in there amongst all natives which is always a good sign with any ethnic restaurant. 

Culturally impersonal and slow service aside, Red Tavern is a great neighborhood restaurant serving delicious Russian eats in a surprisingly upscale atmosphere http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iQEbftkjbnP3QrvHLhJaAg?select=tOs1W-4JvGcmPGxPWtVZIw#am3w0cH3gQHb3qdx3cUYjA. 

As my first "real" experience with Russian cuisine, I found it to be most similar to Greek and German cuisine with things like Zucchini Pancakes, Schnitzel, and Kebabs on the menu. We started with the Zucchini Pancakes w/ Salmon Tartar & Sour Cream ($8.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iQEbftkjbnP3QrvHLhJaAg?select=tOs1W-4JvGcmPGxPWtVZIw#tOs1W-4JvGcmPGxPWtVZIw which were delightful (no comparison to Kokkari's though). The pancakes could have been crisper but they were delicious nonetheless with the silky smooth smoked salmon, "salsa", and creamy sour cream. As one of my favorite offal meats, our second appetizer of Grilled Beef Tongue w/ Creamy Horseradish Sauce ($9.50) didn't disappoint http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iQEbftkjbnP3QrvHLhJaAg?select=tOs1W-4JvGcmPGxPWtVZIw#3u3VcwzRs6vvTooH2p4YFg . The tongue was so soft and tender with a slight bite to it. The grill marks added a lovely smoky nuance. Carniwhores would rejoice over their Meat Platter of Rack of Lamb, Chicken & Lamb Lula ($42) for 2-3 people; 2 people if you're dining with a dude or 1 Mr. NSS who ate 3/4ths the platter and would have eaten the whole thing by himself if I wasn't there. MEAT HOG! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iQEbftkjbnP3QrvHLhJaAg?select=tOs1W-4JvGcmPGxPWtVZIw#TJ_oJAJanLz5PO_w0ZUtPg. The trio of meats all were wonderfully seasoned and grilled to a nice tenderness and served with a homemade sauce similar to a BBQ sauce but with a HUGE punch tangy piquancy. The Lamb Lula (kebab) was my favorite as it was rich and fatty with a mouth-watering earthy spice blend. I didn't touch the accompanying potato gratin but the grilled zucchini, bell peppers, and onions were al-dente with a delicious garlickyness. 

Red Tavern is definitely worth a trek to the Outer Richmond to get your Russian carniwhore eats ON. RAWRRRR!

Please don't call me a tiger now. *Evil Eye*
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I could have give 5 stars to red tavern, but then i was a bit disappointed because they didn't have a few dishes that i wanted to order and service was kinda slow...so 4 stars for you this time!

It's a cute little restaurant located on clement. I've never heard of it and I've never had russian food. I choose to go here for my birthday celebration all because of fellow yelpers~ Thanks for the nice recommendation! 

Food was really good. The zucchini pancakes was delicious! Roasted prawns drown in the creamy garlic sauce was heaven! I did ask for more bread so I could dip it in the sauce but....the bread never came! I was impressed with the grill beef tongue. It was so soft and almost melt in my mouth! 

We had the small veal dumplings. That reminded me of ravioli and chinese wonton~ It's something in between, very interesting and I did like it~ For the main entree we had the beef stroganoff and tavern meat platter. The beef stroganoff was a bit too oily for me but it tasted good. The meat platter was pretty good too~ 

We finished our dinner with some vanilla cream puff. Too bad they ran out of blinis so we couldn't order those special russian desserts! If you have never had russian, I would totally recommend Red Tavern. Hopefully they won't run of of blinis next time!
author: Louisa L.

description: This place is absolutely amazing. Food is great, we felt completely at home. The owner is absolutely great and very hospitable. Will definitely return!
author: Nuriya S.

description:
Very good Russian and Georgian food, good value for money and good service.

I've been to the Red Tavern 4 times already and the food keeps on impressing me.
I'm no stranger to Russian food. I've been to the limited selection of authentic Russian restaurants and, after home cooked Russian food, this comes at a very close second place.

From the bread, through the fish, the soups and the dough dishes and main courses down to desert - it's all fabulous. I'm not sure what the wienerschnitzel is doing on the menu, but I'll bet it isn't bad.

Prices are very reasonable. We usually do family style (with Baltika 9s all around) and end up with ~ $30 a person. They are pretty full on weekends and spookishly empty on weekdays, but make no mistake - this is an A+ gastronomic experience as far as Russian/Georgian food go.
author: Oren R.

description: We came here on a Sunday afternoon because it was the only non-Asian restaurant open around. We knocked on the door about 40 min (12:20PM) before the restaurant was supposed to open and a gentleman opened the door and stated that we had to wait till 1 PM. I asked twice if they were going to open for sure. He said yes. The inside looked like a total mess after the Saturday banquet or something but we were hopeful that the restaurant management would keep the word. We waited for 40 minutes at the door and exactly at one this quick-tempered madame shows up and attacks us with her attitude, unacceptable tone of voice and dirty looks. She told us to go away as they were closed for banquets. Shocked by the appearance of this aggressive lady, we were speechless at first but then we told her that they should have warned us 40 minutes ago. Needless to say, the conversation was not a pleasant one. All 4 of us were absolutely shocked and disappointed by this woman's inappropriate behavior, aggression, barbaric manners, and plain inability to run a business.  3 of us were ashamed of her as our country-mate. Dear customers, if you happen to come across that lady, please remember NOT all Russians are like that!!! There are good, polite people out there and so are better, friendlier restaurants.
author: Lady H.

description: I had a great time at Red Tavern, the food was great, from the borscht to the olive salad was fantastic ...we ordered Tavern Meat Platter, with lamb and chicken kebob... the lamb was so good, it melted in my mouth... i was shocked how good it was... the atmosphere was great too with fun Russian music in the background....  food was great, the waiter was fun, he was right off the the boat from Moscow, spoke little English...but he was trying hard to make sure we had a good time.... Also,  parking in that area is impossible, but there was valet parking across the street... Good Russian food is hard to find, we drove all the way from redwood city to San Francisco to dine there..It was gamble that paid off.....i am not sure if they are that good or we caught them on a good night....but we sure had a lot of fun and i will be back again really soon....
author: Joe D.

description: An accidental find but phenomenal! Sour cherry dumplings with sour cream are a must have. We enjoyed the beef stroganoff and sautéed cabbage quite a bit. The hit of the meal was dessert, Russian syrniki with sour cream and fruit compote. We will definitely return!
author: April C.

description: Outstanding. Comfortable, very friendly, accommodating people. Wonderful food. Generous portions. Exotic to a westerner without being strange. Will definitely be back.
author: Jean B.

description:
Wow. What an amazing meal w/exceptional service. Honestly, if it hadn't been for a class assignment, my roommate and I would probably have never gotten to taste Russian cuisine. Man am I thankful. We were honored to be served by Katia (probably butchering her name), who was so rich w/knowledge when it came to Russian culture and it's food. Upon her recommendation, we tried borsch (beets, cabbage, beef soup), olivie (salad w/eggs, potatoes, beef, and peas), beef stroganoff (beef sauteed w/mushrooms and cream), and napolean cake (flaky, vanilla cream cake). 
I'm a self proclaimed "foodie" so I was so excited to try it all. The food was AMAZING. I'm not a fan of beets, but the soup was surprisingly delicious. A lot of the dishes were so flavorful w/out being overpoweringly sweet/salty/sour/etc. The dishes seemed well balanced and didn't make me have that heavy gross feeling you usually have after tons of meat and heavy cream. 
Our server was so helpful and really made our experience a memorable one. She was so sweet and explained the different Russian customs and ingredients. She even let us sample some traditional Russian treats and drinks! 
I will definitely be back to try the rest of the menu!
P.S. The ambiance is muy classy
author: Emily M.

description:
Mediocre. My food was too salty, too fat (even for Russian food), undercooked; in general it felt like it was made from house leftovers rather than fresh made. Server didn't ask if everything was OK or if I wanted anything else, brought my main dish before I finished appetizer, and the former got cold. 
I am Russian and know how good Russian food can be. I don't recommend this place.
author: Anastasia K.

description: I was not familiar with the menu or Russian food in general, but our waitress made excellent recommendations of foods just made. Everything was very fresh and full of flavor. Super authentic and very delicious.
author: Jon U.

description: I was down to eat something different and Russian food was in the list for my next yelp reviews. Thanks to yelpers I picked the right restaurant. Red Tavern offers a testy menu. The decor replicates some of the Russian Czar era.For younger audiences it could feel just old.  I had the beef stroganoff  which was delicious but the winner of the menu for the night  was the appetizer *Herring with olives, red onions, lemon. Good service too. :^)
author: Coté M.

description: Food is good, service is not friendly and welcoming. Menu is overpriced. Also music was kind of inappropriate for the restaurant.
author: Rafael M.

description: Real authentic food. I have tried Russian food in New York, L.A., Chicago, Boston, Seattle, and a few other cities - this is really the Best! Nice atmosphere, friendly attentive servers, cute decor makes it a go to place for true home-made food from mother Russia! Czar Nikolai would have been impressed! We have had 3 different soups, 3 appetizers, 3 different main courses - all were very different and very very good!  And, of course, the dessert - out of this world! If you are up for trying this very old and European cuisine - you have found it in San Francisco. A few other tables with number of guests all seemed to enjoy and savoir their dishes as much as we did! I strongly recommend Red Tavern for your next place to taste and explore home-made fresh, hot from the stove (not from the microwave) delicious food.
author: Alexandra S.

description:
Came here on a foggy, chilly night to warm up like the Russians do. There was a banquet table full of people speaking what sounded like Russian when we came in (looked like a birthday party), which was a sign of delicious food to come. 

Service was a bit slow, but friendly enough. Our waiter seemed distracted by the large party, as did the rest of the staff. But the owner came over and apologized for the distraction, so we didn't  mind. Plus, the food more than made up for it.

Here's what we got (all SO GOOD):

Borsch: Loved it. Rivals NY's fancy schmancy Russian Tea Room for my favorite borsch. Quality sour cream as well.

Potato vareniki: Another huge hit. Half-Polish boyfriend was in heaven with the pillow-y Russian-style pierogi.

Zucchini pancakes: Also really delicious. The salmon tasted extremely fresh.

Grilled beef tongue: If you don't like this, then you just don't like tongue. I love lengua in my tacos, but this was the best, simplest beef tongue I've ever had.

Stuffed cabbage rolls: Again, the best cabbage rolls I've ever had. The stuffing was moist and dense, but it didn't overwhelm the cabbage. And the tomato sauce? I'd drink that. 

If this sounds like a lot of food for two people, it was. We ordered way too much food because we were so excited to try everything. I don't regret it one bit.
author: Ashley C.

description:
Red Tavern is only six months old, so there's a few kinks to work out. My recent evening here, however, showed genuine promise. The staff is determined, the food is great and it's only a matter of time until this becomes a destination restaurant.

The restaurant was alive with Russian families celebrating with Baltika, Georgian wine and Borjomi. The food was fresh and well-prepared, featuring items like rabbit and sturgeon. The waiters were literally working up a sweat serving a packed house on Friday night.

Standout dishes include the Russian Bliny Tower, featuring fresh salmon roe, sweet crepes and smoked sturgeon. The rabbit stew has an rich cream sauce and falls off the bone. And I'd recommend two orders of the smoked herring--firm, moist and packed with flavor.

There are a few areas for improvement. With only two waiters, orders and dishes require patience. The kitchen produces quality food, but it's not quick. We waited about 40 minutes between starters and mains. These problems, however, are common with new restaurants and should resolve over time.

And yes, they could use a liquor license. I imagine vodka sales would dramatically improve their bottom line and bring in riotous private parties. For now, however, enjoy some quality seafood and discover the bounty of the Outer Richmond.
author: Karl H.

description:
We came here for dinner on a Wednesday night after we flew up to SF from LA.  My husband is Russian and only enjoys the cooking by his babushka but he had found the Red Tavern on yelp and thought he'd give it a try.  And we enjoyed it quite immensely.  
We ordered the smoked fish platter, borchst, zucchini pancakes and stuffed cabbage.  We shared all the dishes and was stuffed afterwards.  A couple of the dishes was a bit salty but not too overwhelming.  
The restaurant is quiet and our server was very attentive and nice.
author: Patty L.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised.  The food was great, the wine was cheap, and the service was fast and friendly.  Decor is very Russian.  Overall, had a fantastic experience here.  

The potato plate (kartoshka) is huge.  One plate could easily be enough for 4 or 5 people. For any one who has never had these fried potatoes drenched in garlic and butter, you are seriously missing out.  I ordered the mushroom julienne (diced mushrooms, cheese) also, which complimented the  potatoes perfectly.  I also loved the potato vareneiki, which reminded me of my grandmother's!  It is essentially a potato dumpling (steamed) and topped off with carmelized onion.  Make sure to ask your waiter for some sour cream to add on top.  With all these tasty carbs, and the complimentary sourdough and rye bread, I was a very happy camper.

Oh, and a huge glass of chardonnay was only $5! That helped (a lot) with the happiness.
author: Gev M.

description:
Ate there twice last week with Serbians and Americans--all were very happy!

A great find!  Eastern European cuisine is underrepresented in San Francisco proper so it is a welcome discovery.

Service was also top notch.

Thanks!
author: Miriam S.

description: My girlfriend and I were on a stroll looking for dinner and we saw this inviting place.  People had tall glasses of beers sitting at nice white table cloth settings.  We thought it was an Italian joint and we got a table. To our surprise it was a Russian restaurant! My first time eating Russian.  We had Borsch, Siberian dumplings, and a Lamb basmati dish.  I will be back and will get the Beef stroganoff!
author: Blood W.

description:
We were really interested to see what would become of this place since it changed ownership and we are just blown away. The food was just fabulous. The place looks really great. 

We ordered the Lobster mac n cheese, mushroom julien, and olivea (russian potato salad), and sturgeon. Everything we had, and I mean everything was just great. The mac n cheese was just luscious and dripping with flavor. The mushrooms were so delicious and creamy! The olivea was just like grandma makes. And the sturgeon was tender and flavorful! 

Portion sizes are very reasonable and they do not skimp out. 

This place is just great and really hits the spot if you want homemade Russian food plus some other great european favorites.
author: Michelle I.

description:
I was here yesterday with the wife and other relatives and group of people for a memorial meal. The food seemed ok at first. But when we left, I felt really heavy in my stomach. The feeling then subsided as the day/evening went on. Some of my in-laws were sick after eating here yesterday.

The thing is that my wife and I wanted to come here to check the place out for ourselves. We did yesterday, albeit under other circumstances. But now we will not be back to actually have a meal here.
author: Vlad F.

description: Holy smokes does this place blow! I made a reservation for four people at 7 PM through open table.  We show up at seven and are "greeted"at the door by the maître d' with lots of attitude and states we are very busy sorry guys. We informed her that we have reservations & she rolls her eyes at us and reluctantly turns around without saying anymore to seat us. Needless to say we did not stay and we left.  CUSTOMER SERVICES SUCKS
author: Alireza A.

description:
With its tasty, home-style Russian cuisine, Red Tavern is a breath of fresh air in the midst of the myriad Asian restaurants in the Richmond.

While a little less crispy that they should be, the zucchini pancakes with salmon tartar ($8.95) were delicious.  The large portion of borscht ($5.95) was one of the very best examples of the genre--rich broth with a nice combination of vegetables and perfect consistency.  Hearty and delicious, the rabbit stew ($18.95) with shallots and Madeira was fall-off-the-bone tender.

At present, drink options are limited to beer and wine:  unfortunately, no vodka or other spirits.  With only four or five selections, the wine list is extremely limited, but it makes up for its brevity with its low prices.  Beer highlights include Staropramen on tap as well as Baltika by the bottle.

Although a bit reserved (typical for Russians), service was quick.  While most dishes arrived at a good pace--neither too fast, nor too slow--the waiter had to be reminded to bring the drinks that were ordered.

With reasonable prices and authentic Eastern European fare, Red Tavern is a good addition to the Richmond.  If you are a fan of Russian food, you will love Red Tavern.  If you are not a fan of Russian food, Red Tavern will turn you into one.
author: CJ G.

description: Delicious food and fantastic service. Delicious Russian wine. Chicken, Kasha, pickled vegetables, and Blini were outstanding. I'm definitely coming back.
author: Clovo S.

description: This restaurant has delicious food. The borscht and stuffed cabbage were great!  I'll definitely be visiting again the next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Elise K.

description:
A little disappointing. Russian food can be absolutely delicious and after being first turned away when we arrived on a weekday night due to a huge private party, we were excited to make it back and finally get to try out the best rated Russian restaurant in SF. Despite the acclaim here on Yelp, that next night we were the only people in the restaurant when we arrived (and only one other couple arrived later).

The smoked fish appetizer was the highlight of the meal with quite tasty thick-cut piece of smokey salmon and sturgeon, but the solyanka (smoked meat soup), the rabbit stew, and the fillet of fish in dill sauce were all disappointing bland. The rabbit was also extremely dry.

Maybe worth another try, but on the expensive side, and overall just sadly not what we were hoping for.
author: Amy D.

description: Had the borsch, zucchini pancakes, beef stroganoff, cabbage rolls, and some mixed berry drink.  The borsch and the crust on the stroganoff were the best parts but that's not saying much.  The zucchini pancakes had the soggy consistency of something that had been reheated in a microwave.  The beef in the stroganoff was dry and tasted like glue.  The cabbage rolls had a little bit better flavor but not anything great.  The server was very pleasant.
author: Neal S.

description: I've grown up eating Russian food made by my parents, and this place definitely met my expectations. The place has a great atmosphere, a bit fancy though so dress accordingly. Now on to my favorite part: the food. Start off with a bowl of their borsch, it's absolutely delicious. I loved how they pair it with some rye Russian bread. Make sure to try the smoked fish selection, and some classics salads like Olivye. My only complaint is the pricing. Most of the dishes (especially the salad) were a bit overpriced, the bill came out to about $45 a person.
author: Olga M.

description:
Continuing on our quest to try every Russian food establishment in the city of SF and surrounding areas, Vicky L. and I came to Red Tavern on a chilly SF night. 

I scored a parking spot across the street so that made me extremely happy. 

We walkied into the restaurant to find a group of 20 older Russians all speaking the language and having some sort of celebration. Vicky wanted to choose a babushka from them. We were seated immediately at a 4 top nearby. 

We split their Borsch, it had beef in it which is unique (in a good way!)
Zucchini pancakes with salmon - this was a great starter to spit since there were 2 pancakes :) I'm not especially fond of zucchini but this I liked! Grated zucchini is formed into cakes and fried topped with a sour cream drizzle and salmon tartar. For my entree, I tried to order cabbage rolls (my go-to item) but they were out, so I went with a chicken dish - I can't remember what it's called! But the chicken was juicy and I loved the sauteed veggies and potatoes on the side. 

Next goal: Try every dish here!
author: Sara P.

description:
My friends and I (a group of 4) came on a Saturday night at around 8pm without a reservation. The restaurant was half empty, which meant we were promptly seated. The ambiance was nice, not too casual or overly stuffy/upscale. For most of us, except for a friend who has Russian family, this was our first time trying Russian food and it was glorious. 

The waitress started us off with complimentary fresh bread and butter.

The dishes:

Borsch (served with sour cream on the side)- Lightly sweet from the beets. There's also nice chunks of tender beef.

Solyanka (served with sour cream on the side)- A hearty soup for the chilly SF nights. A nice smoked meat flavor and they don't skimp of the meat. 

Combination of Pickled Vegetables- consisted of pickles, pickled cabbage and cherry tomatoes. Very refreshing to eat between heavy meat dishes. The veggies were lightly briney.

Baltic Herring- served with thinly sliced, pickled red onions, olives and slices of lemon. On my first bite, I was surprised at the intensity of fish's flavor, which was very briney and salty. I guess I expected this dish to taste like smoked herring. This herrings' "fishness" flavor was very concentrated. The intense flavor complemented nicely with the more subtle ones of Pan-Fried Potatoes.

Pan-Fried Potatoes Home Style- thinly sliced potatoes panfried with garlic and dill. Some parts were crispy and others were more lightly fried. A variety of friedness for everyone. So delicious, I kept munching on these even after I thought my stomach would burst from all the food. 

Siberian Style Pelmeny (with veal) - My favorite dish of the night! Good god, these dumplings tasted like little pillows of heaven. The dough had a little bite to them. The meat filling is so velvety, unctuous, juicy. Put a little sour cream over them. These are so decadent that you don't need to eat much of them to feel satisfied. 

Cabbage Rolls- My least favorite dish of the night. I'm not sure if I'm into the ground meat rolled in cabbage combo. There weren't any flavors that really stood out to me. But my friends really liked this dish.

Overall, the food was well prepared and delicious. The flavors were simple but memorable. Our dishes came out quickly, within 5- 10 minutes. Our waitress was attentive but not over-bearing. The only real downside to this place is that parking is horrible (but that can be said for all of sf).
author: Julia T.

description: The food is excellent. Totally excellent. The service, we had a young waitress who seemed completely annoyed that we asked for food in a restaurant. However, I don't really care when the stroganoff is THAT good.
author: Clint T.

description: Happy to give my five stars to this place. We came here in a big group, there was nine of us. They sat us promptly, the server was very friendly and accommodating. Food was delicious. I had beef stroganoff, my wife had chicken kebab, my sister had golubtsy (meet balls in cabbage leafs) - everything tasted great. They have good selection of beer. Their kompot ( fruit drink) is very good too. Highly recommended!
author: Tommy H.

description:
The favorite place and nice restaurant . We've been here several times with my gf. Everything was perfect except one food.
Luli kebab was old or I dont know. It was really bad and we didnt eat even. But Pelmeny, Beef tongue , salads and chicken kebabs were good . I love this place but i'll never order Luli kebab anymore.
author: Jay M.

description: This place is delicious. We were worried because there weren't many people inside, but the food was great. It's actually better because the food comes out fast! The other reviews didn't lead us wrong.
author: Ian W.

description: I wish i was not stuffed and would have dinner here. I just wanted Napoleon and tea, but ended up with prunes with walnuts :-) Food looks awesome. Definitely recommend this place and will be back here when will be in the town.
author: Marina G.

description: Excellent Russian food...pleasant ambiance and great selection of authentic dishes. Perfect place for a large party or intimate dinner for two. Definitely will be coming back for more...
author: Lina S.

description: The food is fantastic.Definitely splurge on the Blini tower,the fish and caviar are awesome! Borscht was really tasty as well.The kebab was perfectly seasoned.My one star off is because they forgot two things we ordered which ended up ok since my Dad and I shared a pretty great amount of stuff.And I think they are understaffed for such a bumping establishment.Other than that,outstanding and will be back
author: Lauren V.

description:
We had the:

zuchini pancakes (fantastic. get. these.)
fried pelmeni (also a great new take on traditional pelmeni)
beef stroganoff (very tender...was just a bit too salty for my taste, but didnt stop me from pigging out)
rabbit stew (i was told it was good by someone who appreciates rabbit meat.... i myself shy away a bit from eating bunnies...no judgement, though =] ) 


the atmosphere was so great! the music was pretty classic and quiet, the light was relaxing, overall the restaurant looks great. Great place to come and just relax without people hustling and bustling all around you. 

the waiter (tall, dark hair, russian) was really great. You know how there's some waiters that come up and ask you if u need anything 50+ times an hour? he wasnt one of those. very patient, very respectful, extremely professional. experienced none of the rudeness touched on below... NOTE: it is not eastern european custom to smile and grin at every stranger, regardless of whether they are a customer. it is customary to save smiles for friends and family, so don't get offended if the staff don't act like they're your BFFs, its nothing personal. 


I am ukrainian myself, so I eat this food very. often. It is much harder to make an impression on someone who grew up on the very same food, but this place does a great job.
author: Alana V.

description: Great service and delicious food! Meat pancakes and tongue are just perfect. Do not skip 'Paris' tea with Napoleon nomnomnom
author: Nadya P.

description: Everything about this place is outstanding. Its my little window to my hometown in Moscow. I love it.
author: Alice C.

description: Absolutely amazing place. Really fancy. Delicious food. I have never tried Russian food before and it definitely left me with a wonderful impression. I tried the beef tongue, the cabbage rolls, the beef stroganoff, the crepes, cream puffs.. Everything was delicious. Not to mention the service was more than satisfying.
author: Ruth B.

description: Feeling nostalgic for the USSR?  RED TAVERN has a "meanwhile in Soviet Russia" vibe you are yearning for. If you're looking for a restaurant that gives you that feeling the people next to you are listening in to your conversation this is the place.  If you want a spot to relax and just drink vodka shots and dried fish,  then here you go,  if you want to eat until you're full as Russian Bear,  da,  this is the place.  RED TAVERN.
author: keith g.

description:
I wanted to try something new near me so I searched Yelp for something different. Saw the 4-Star rating so we decided to come here. I was able to make a reservation for same night (in 20 minutes in fact) on Opentable. 

Once here, the BF and I were pleased with the beautiful interior. 

There were two large parties (8+) and a group of 5 so we were able to pick our own table. The waiter/host was nice but a little serious. 

After we were seated, I had to summon the other waiter who was leaning against the bar counter doing nothing. He was not as warm and nice. 

We ordered the the grilled beef tongue, zucchini pancakes, rabbit stew, and pork schnitzel.  The BF ordered a cab and I the Russian Root Beer which were both fine.  We also ordered the French Coffee Glasse for dessert. 

Well, the beef tongue came out first, the BF LOVED IT, but I thought it was just ok.

Then came our main courses. The BF enjoyed his schnitzel but was expecting it to be crispier.  I found the rabbit stew to be very creamy but nothing spectacular. It was under-seasoned in my opinion. 

The zucchini pancakes never made it to our table. Sigh. 

The French Coffee Glasse was good but you can't really go wrong with an affogado, can you?

So the overall experience is somewhere between 2-3 stars but I decided to give it 3 stars because the first waiter/host was very cute. Haha.

As a side note, a lady whom I thought is the Owner/Manager/Overlord was uber friendly and talkative with one of the larger groups. She was NOT friendly and did not make any attempt to make the rest of the patrons feel welcome. In fact, I locked eyes with her twice, and both times, she Just gave me an empty, almost hostile look. Oh yeah, she was wearing a turquoise jacket with parachute pants!
author: William L.

description:
Just had a lovely Valentine dinner at Red Tavern. The service was warm and attentive, the food delicious and the beer and wine perfect! We'll be back to try more of the authentic dishes.
J. Harris
author: Judi H.

description: The food and a service  are outstanding. Uniq authentic delicious food. Recommend it to all. Must visit.
author: Aleksey M.

description: Good quality Russian food and a great place to go with a big group. Also the best Napoleon cake in SF.
author: Eugene Z.

description: I came here for a family friend's birthday. The service was a bit slow but they were polite and nice. The food was really good. The lamb was a bit dry...but i liked the sauce :) I also liked the assorted smoked fish and the olives were good too. I would come back here again.
author: Wanda M.

description:
Yum!
Beef tongue
Pelmini
Zucchini pancakes.

+ Soup, split for 2, is the perfect order for 2.
author: Ami Y.

description: I was left extremely happy with Red Tavern. They serve amazing food and provide great service to their customers. I would highly recommend this restaurant for all occasions including a nice evening out with your significant other or a big family gathering!
author: Mark S.

description: Authentic Russian food, authentic Russian people  - in short if you want to experience truly russian atmosphere it is the best place to go. The prices are affordable too. Please do not mind the customers - in Russia people dont smile too much )))
author: George B.

description: I grew with Ukrainians in New York so I loved and didn't love this place. The varenyky were amazing. The smoked fish plate was so salty it was hard to take, but the people I was with loved it. Blitzes were pretty greasy. The portions of everything are bigger than you'd expect so definitely consider sharing. It was refreshing for me since I miss my grandmas cooking. So if you want a reminder of the recipes of your past, I'd give it a shot.
author: Lauren A.

description:
Let me start with a statement... I was born in Moscow, Russia.. I am super picky about my Russian food (yup, I can make amazing Russian food at home, it is just super time consuming!).
i was at Red tavern about 4 times I think - it is pretty good Russian food for a reasonable price. 
From a Russian gal - here are my recommendations: 
Pelmieni - is a must, you might want to try Chinicaly as well (I am totally not sure about the spelling!)
If you are ok with potato salad - try Olivie
All smoked/salted fish there is great and fresh. 
I would stick to traditional Russian/Georgian foods, skip the more "international" ones. 
Meats - are great. 

All in all - great place, I hope more people will come here. 
Our service was mostly good - I hope that if people had a bad experience that was an exception and not the rule.
author: Nastia R.

description:
For the first time ever, my wife and I went to a Russian Restaurant. Really didn't know what to expect. We were pleasantly surprised of the variety of appetizers and entrees they offered.

We end up having multiple appetizers and there was no room left for any entree after that. I guess this is a good reason to go back soon;-)

The Russian Blynis (Crepes) Tower, Blatic Heering, Pan Friend Potato, and the grilled beef tongue are just magnificent.
author: Ramin S.

description: It's pricey then again it's San Francisco. I had the cabbage rolls. 3 cabbage rolls for 17 dollars it didn't come with anything else. The bf had the beef Stroganoff I liked that better the sauce was nice and rich. The Russian beer selection is good I picked #3 and it was nice and smooth. I forgot which # beer BF picked but it was a dark beer. I"m not a big fan of dark beer because of the after taste but these beers didn't have a noticeable aftertaste so that was enjoyable. The borscht is good too a little salty but it was tasty. I want to come back and try the prune dessert.
author: Clara H.

description: The quality of the meal is so so and absolutely doesn't reflect the price and portions are rather small!!! I don't recommend to try lulya kebab, cause they cook it like a cutlet with lot's of oil. Solyanka is ok, but for this price it should be something more than ok. Dumplings are rather ordinary and taste like they were bought in one of russian shops in SF and they just boiled them.
author: Igor R.

description:
Depending on my second visit, I will give and update, but so far its 4 stars for me. Well, its a pretty Russian place, only maybe if they could print out a menu in Russian (their menu is printed on a sheet of thick paper so might as well print one out in Russian for those with limited knowledge of English and a good knowledge of Russian? My relatives who visit turn out this way).

I've been to one other place and their food portion were quite small and they were a bit on the pricy side. We were a party of 6 and all ordered different food. I had the chance to try some of those, and I could tell they were pretty good. Their soup was quite delicious, the pelmeni were awesome. I was tempted to order the Lula kebab but I opted for a Shish kebab which was alright. Next time definitely Lula kebab! Since I was driving, I couldn't enjoy the beer but my uncle did have 2 pints of Baltika 6. Again, for the next time.

But yeah, if you guys are nearby and feeling for Russian food, Red Tavern is the place to go!
author: Sap S.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Monday night.
We ordered the solyanka soup, grilled beef tongue and meat trio.  The soup was hearty and satisfying. The chicken in the trio was not bad but the lamb was a bit gamey. The beef tongue was decent. For dessert we had the crepe with strawberry jelly which was delightful and not too heavy.
author: Jennie W.

description:
Sunday night, day four of my five day celebration of gluttony tour of San Francisco we decided since we had eaten Korean, Chinese, Vietnamese and Salvadorean food it was time for some European food.  We found Red Tavern on Yelp and into the GPS the address went.  When we got to the restaurant It turned out it was all booked for the night.  Calling ahead is a good idea sometimes.  So we made a reservation for our last meal of our vacation at Red Tavern the next day.

Let me start with the bad.  There was only one waitress and apparently only one cook working.  So even though the restaurant was relatively empty(14 customers at four tables) they struggled to keep up.  In general the service was slow.  Our waitress was very friendly and apologetic about the slowness.

That being said when our food did arrive we completely forgot about the slowness.  

To start we have the smoked fish platter.  In the interest of full disclosure I really like smoked fish and theirs did not disappoint.

We choose the pork schnitzel and the Beef Cheek Stew for dinner with the Tavern Potatoes(I like Dan Q's spelling), Kasha, Fried Cauliflower, and Garlic Potatoes.

The Schnitzel was great!  As good as any I got in my two years in Germany.  The Cheek stew tasted like it had been slowly cooked for hours imparting all of its' beefy flavors in the wonderfully caramelized sauce.  We both agreed the Kasha and the Garlic potatoes would have been great except they were so overshadowed by the Cauliflower and more so the Tavern potatoes that by comparison they were almost  pedestrian.  If you go you must try the Tavern potatoes.  They are soft and dense and just cheesy enough to be delicious without being greasy.

It was definitely a very disappointing realization that I live a six hour flight away so it will be a long while before I can come back for more of their delicious food.
author: Brad P.

description: First time try Russian food. It was amazing! Five stars! Not very hungry, but ate everything at the end! Love it!
author: I X.

description: I was in this restaurant around 3 weeks ago. Staff is ruddy a little bit, but food is delicious. I think i will come here again with my family. I wanted to write bad review, but they give me discount on plov (i waited it 50 minutes), and the waiter apologized, i was happy. But anyway i paid full check and was surprised.
author: Rinat B.

description:
I love good food, And this place never lets me down, I'm not russian but I love the
Flavoring of their foods. Try the potato dumplings! And get the rabbit stew. Both are awesome
author: Andrew J.

description:
We were in the Outer Richmond and thought it would be a great idea to check out a nearby Russian restaurant, after finding out that we were nearby via Yelp.

We got there rather early for dinner and there was only one other party when we came in, but as soon as we walked in I felt that this was the real deal when it comes to Russian food - and it certainly didn't disappoint. 

There were three of us and we ordered a fair amount of food to share - zucchini pancakes, cabbage rolls, schnitzel, lamb kabob, mushrooms over cheese and a couple of side dishes - cauliflower, grilled vegetables and crispy potatoes. Probably the best was the zucchini pancakes, cabbage rolls and lamb... Schnitzel was great but nothing fancy while the mushrooms/cheese mix was smaller than I expected and nothing to rave about. All of the food overall though was absolutely delicious and rather filling. We still had room for dessert though - had the prunes with walnuts inside which may sound like a weird mix but we finished the whole thing. 

Would definitely recommend checking it out and would certainly go back.
author: Lisette P.

description: Wanted to grab lunch. Server was very rude. Had 5 open tables - he said he could not put them together. Tried to reason with server- he said he was too busy for us to talk. Did not offer any alternatives ...
author: Vera B.

description:
Had another excellent time at The Red Tavern. We got the Olivia Salad which is a Russian Christmas speciality. It was made potatoes, meet, peas, pickles, mayonnaise and carrots. It was to die for, as close as my Grandmother use to make. 

Next, we had the Cucumber Salad made with fresh dill, sour cream, and green onions another spot on dish. The next appetizer was the fried Pelmeny which was very good served with fresh homemade Sour Cream. 

For the main dish we had the Meet Combination which consisted of Rack of Lamb, Lamb Lu Lu, Chicken with potatoes and fresh vegetables. It was out of this world. 

The service was exceptional. They had two large parties going on when we were there and we were served promptly and courtesely. 

One last thing is their wines. You need to try the Georgian Red Wine. Very full bodied and colorful.
author: Nick D.

description:
This is a very good place for a family dinner, holiday,  party.
If you enjoy European cuisine, offers a fine selection of Russian and Georgian menu!
Hungry you do not get out of here! All will be eaten to the last crumb.
The only thing that some may not like it, it's a combination of meat and potatoes.
If you are on a diet.
But this particular Russian traditions!
I recommend to Meat Platter of Rack of Lamb, Chicken /Lamb Lula, Siberian Pelmeni, Borsch, Grilled Beef Tongue w/ Creamy Horseradish Sauce - it's just lick your fingers!
Beautifully decorated hall, fresh food, nice atmosphere.
Only the supply of free time, because the service is not fast.
Russian love to sit for a long time in good company, with a long conversation with a glass of vodka and a great snack!
author: Olga B.

description: The food here was pretty good. We had the buffet style dinner and it came with a ton of options and way too much food that was pretty much breakfast and lunch the next day. They also let me bring my own wine at no corkage fee which was awesome :)
author: Tanya S.

description:
Worst service ever in my life!

We waited 20 minutes to get our order taken. We got some of our dishes before we got any drinks. Then, the waiter forgot to bring the rest of our order and we had to ask for it later. Also, our bill was wrong and the servers did not bother to get our check for at least 15-20 minutes after we were ready.

At least the food was good and the atmosphere was pleasant. Overall, it would have been a nice experience if we got adequate attention.
author: Mirela S.

description: Rabbit stew had bones in it was average, Uzbek plov was lacking spices but lamb was tender, Lula kebab was not good I didn't finish it. Solyanka didn't not resemble real soviet era solyanka at all. I don't recommend this place if you are a true gourmet. If you don't really know how anything should taste you won't know the difference probably. Place is small but very clean. Area is shady and we had to beg convenience stores to give us quarters for parking here.
author: Kamila N.

description: Called the day of to make reservations for a party of 12, lady over the phone recommended we do a pre fix menu. Looked over the two different options for the pre fix dinners that were available, decided on the one that was $65 per a person. Man O man I couldn't have been any happier. Every person was literally stuffed and on top of that there were leftovers to take home. Lots of yummy apps to eat before the meat came out. The lamb chops were really good! Then came the dessert which is a traditional russian cake. Even though I was stuffed I had to have a bite of that cake, after the first bite I couldn't resist on finishing the entire piece. Waitress was really nice and explained what everything was on the table, she was very attentive and kept checking on us throughout the entire dinner even when there was nothing left to bring out. Def going to go back because it appears there are several items I would really enjoy that didn't come as part of the pre fix dinner.
author: Dmitriy G.

description:
I've never tried Russian good until yesterday. One of my co-worker is leaving the company so we had a farewell gather with him. He being Russian, of course recommended everyone to give Russian food a try and i don't regret it one bit.This place is fairly tiny and our party took up about half of the restaurant. 

I do highly recommend ordering the ox-tongue, it is so tender it almost just melts in your mouth. You can eat it as it or with the purple-relish-look-a-like thing which is suppose to be like wasabi. I didn't like it one bit, so i ate the ox-tongue plain. We also had this cabbage wrapped with minced pork on the inside. Which was actually very good also, being just wrapped in cabbage the meat does fall apart but because the way how it's cook it's mix in with some soup so it's delicious. 

I will come back to Red Tavern for another dinner. The food here is great and the service is outstanding.
author: Jenny G.

description:
I love this place. We wandered in on a weekend when I was feeling homesick (eastern part of Europe) and wanted some familiar food.

The place won me over right off the bat with presentation. The waiter was dressed like a proper waiter and they have actual table cloths that looked nice. I KNOW - who the heck cares right? Well I find very few things tackier than the paper they put on top of most tables in SF restaurants.

The food is awesome, but have to be careful how you pace yourself. They are big portions and the dishes are rather heavy. 

We tried and were very pelased with
- Lobster Mac and Cheese AMAZING and rather large portion
- Borscht Soup - this one hit home. LOVED it, though a little sweeter then my mom's
- Polenta dish 
- Stuffed cabbage 
- sardines
and I am pretty sure we ordered a couple of other ones to try out (my friends were at their first east European cuisine experience), none disapointed
And the jug of beer to top it all off....it was awesome!

There was a Russian family celebrating what seemed to be a birthday - there was lots of cake and kids and family and conversation and laughter..nothing could have made this a better experience all around. I definitely got the familiar feeling I was looking for.

Will be coming back here for sure!
author: Em S.

description:
Well...it was my first time there...I was not impressed from first minute...SERVICE WAS HORRIBLE! Waiter Tatyana was very unfriendly,never smiled We didn't feel welcome at the restaurant... My guest felt uncomfortable with this service And i should pays tips for this. Guys..COME ON! I paid money!!! 
Food: food was pretty good! But they missed few items that was on the our banquet menu...))) Would not recommend.
author: Cali F.

description:
What a shame!
I called them and made reservation with the owner, when we came over  for a dinner (it was 10 min later than reserved time), they just finished big party and nothing was ready for us. Nobody was even paying attention that we are standing at the doors. When I finally found the manager, he said that we have to wait another 15 min, when I asked to talk to the owner ( who took my reservation on the phone), she didn't even think to come to us and apologize, instead she pretty rudely said from the distance: if you dont want to wait - it is up to you, you can leave.
Please don't go to that place unless you really miss "russian/soviet" type of service
author: Mike G.

description:
A very interesting restaurant.  I too have never actually sat in a Russian restaurant before, but looking at the menu, I basically stuck to the things that I have tried before:

Beef Stroganoff: Now I love beef stroganoff, but I was very confused at first when it came out in a puff pastry form, almost like a pot pie for the beef stroganoff.  Normally I have beef stroganoff with egg noodles and I like that.  But in the pot pie form, I thought it was very interesting and the taste of the stroganoff was very familiar to my palate.

Kasha: I chose kasha as my side dish and it was cooked very nicely.

The dining experience was very nice.  The restaurant was very nicely decorated and had the feeling of a higher end restaurant, but had moderate pricing of food.

Overall, I would recommend if you are curious to try different cuisines out there.
author: Lawrence E.

description:
Classy European restaurant, with great choice of delicious food and friendly ambience.I went there with my husband for a lunch, and wasn't disappointed with our choice at all. It's a small place, and there was only one waiter (Sergey) on the floor-but he did a great job. We didn't have to ask twice for anything, he was on top of it.We ordered Borsch- red cabbage soup with sour cream and Pelmeni- dumplings with meat, Olivje-russian meat salad and Tabacca-chicken. For two of us it was more than enough. The portions are't huge, but the food is very filling. What i liked a lot was that none of the dishes was greasy. My borsch was hot and flavorful. The prices were very reasonable as well. For all these yams + Spaten German Beer and Fruit Drink we paid a little over $50, which is not much.
Over all we had a great experience, we will come back soon!!
author: Anastasia K.

description: I have never been a fan of traditional Russian cuisine, so I was tentative about trying this restaurant.  I have to say I LOVE this place!  The food was so tasty, the staff was extremely kind and it was an overall fun experience.  I'm looking forward to my next visit...
author: David T.

description:
Being adventurous eaters, my companion and I decided on a whim to try Red Tavern on August 31. That fateful day has gone down in history as one of the worst dining experiences either of us has ever had.

We arrived in the mid-afternoon and the place was about 1/4 or 1/3 full, certainly not busy. We were seated promptly and then BLATANTLY IGNORED. Every other table was attended to except ours. Two other groups arrived after us and their orders were taken and drinks and bread served before we could get the waiter's attention. Each time someone came out of the kitchen, we tried to signal that we were ready to order, but the waiter's eyes were downcast and averted. We resorted to waving our arms and saying loudly "Excuse me!" but no luck. After a while, a lady customer on the other side of the restaurant made eye contact with me, and when the waiter returned to her table, she informed him that we were trying to get his attention. Only after this were we on his radar.

After some more waiting, our food arrived (we ordered the zucchini pancakes, which were quite delish, and cabbage roll, which was like someone's mom's mediocre meatloaf with a single leaf of cooked cabbage around it), and we ordered a tea service for two to follow our meal. While we ate, a TERMINIX EXTERMINATOR walked in the front door with his equipment and went straight into the kitchen. He left and returned with additional gear, again entering through the front door and walking across the dining room in full view of the customers. This did in fact happen, and we have photos as evidence. Neither my companion nor myself have ever seen an exterminator in a restaurant. Why didn't he go through the back door? Why didn't he come while the restaurant was closed and there were no customers?

My companion and I decided to cancel the tea service that we had ordered because we wanted to leave after seeing the exterminator. After a few more attempts to summon the waiter, we told him that we no longer wanted the tea. Somehow during that brief and straightforward exchange, there was a miscommunication and he returned with two large white mugs. We were left scratching our heads because 1) he didn't understand our request and 2) other customers who had ordered tea were served lovely delicate china teacups and teapots.

The terrible service, the exterminator, the fact that we were undeniably treated differently from and poorer than the other customers -- it all amounted to a horrible dining experience. I would urge you never to patronize this restaurant.
author: Johanna K.

description: We were guest at a Russian Event in Red Tavern. The food was exceptional (3 course russian food.) and the staff was very helpful.
author: M G.

description:
To the waitstaff: did you know if you're nice to customers, you get better tips?!?! Conversely, if you continue acting like a rude asshole, you get less tips. See how that works? :)

Despite the service, I love this place. I feel like I'm at my grandma's house when I come here. I took an out of town visitor here because I wanted him to have a true Russian experience, complete with delicious Russian food and horrible Soviet service. Red Tavern didn't disappoint! I've been here several times and am slowly making my way down the list. 

Things to try:
Borscht
Solyanka
Bread
Garlic potatoes (side dish)
Zucchini pancakes
Things to skip:
Pelmeni soup and vareniki  (just tasted like something from the frozen section of the supermarket but to be honest, it reminded me of what I ate as a kid)
Fish (it's only there to please the one vegetarian at your table, it's not meant to be a culinary masterpiece but even then it wasn't bad)
Bitocheck (pork schnitzel but without the breading. Kinda boring but tender meat)

The server gave my sister attitude over a misunderstanding. He also forgot my friend's order of hinkali so he had to wait a million years for it to come, but much to our surprise, it did come. We rounded out the evening with spectacularly average and dry desserts from one of the bakeries on Geary, and were kicked out 5 minutes later when the store closed. But I digress. 
Another time we were the last guests in the restaurant but there was still much time left till closing.  We had to wait almost an hour once we were done eating for the hostess to show up. The whole time, there was no staff to be found anywhere. I actually had to get up and go into the kitchen where I found one cook who got her. She did apologize, saying she didn't want to "interrupt" us. Learn some manners people!!

-Your American Comrade
author: daria d.

description: I liked this place a lot. I was there on September 18 2015 with my mother-in-law and her sister. We ordered 6 dishes to share (zucchini pancakes, olivie salad, chicken dumplings, potato dumplings, herring, fried potatoes).  All the dishes were very tasty and the portions were big. You could tell that they were freshly prepared.  Plus the prices were very reasonable. I will definitely go there again.
author: Helen K.

description:
I was devastated when Sadko closed because it was the only place that I know of in the city that served my beloved solyanka (AKA heaven in a bowl). So I was super psyched to learn that the place re-opened under a new name with new owners and a new atmosphere but with the same solyanka on the menu. And what's better on a cold, rainy date night than steamy solyanka! So to Red Tavern we went. 

The food was divine. In addition to the solynaka (just as heavenly as I remembered), we got the summer salad, the potato vareniki, and the rabbit stew. With the breads, it was A LOT of food! And all of it was perfect and delicious and most definitely worth returning for. 

So why only three stars, you ask? I'm glad you asked. The service was sssslllloooowwww. Like slowsky slowosky sloskiski slow. Close to 2 hours slow. It was also really, really cold. Clement Street is cold--there's no way around it. Most restaurants accommodate for this by curtaining off the door area from the rest of the restaurant. I strongly, strongly encourage the new owners to do this. There was no getting away from not only the draft from the door every time it opened (and really, even when it wasn't opened) but also from the chain smokers who smoke right outside of the door (yes, nasty). 

I'm delighted that I have a place to go for heaven in a bowl again, and that the rest of the menu is just as great. But they need a few little tweaks to make it perfect. I hope they hurry up so I can return!
author: Amy B.

description: This is the best place to have family dinner or a small celebration.The food is always fresh and delicious. The service is outstanding. Highly recommend to try this place, specially Napoleon cake. Thank you owners for always keeping your place welcomed and providing great atmosphere with yummy food.
author: Nelya S.

description:
My wife & I wanted to have Russian food for our anniversary. We decided to go here on the way to Pacifica (Lighthouse Hotel).
Honestly, neither of us has had Russian food before & didn't know what to expect. 
The waiter was really Russian and after some translation, told us what he liked best.
We had dumpling with beef, cabbage rolls and home potatoes. Totally terrific! I think we'll be going back.
author: John W.

description: I recently used Red Tavern to cater an event for a group of Russians after getting a recommendation (this person was also Russian). I worked with Irina, the owner, selected the menu since I don't know much about Russian food. She was so easy to work with and really lovely. More important, the food was fantastic -- so tasty. It got rave reviews and every bit of it was eaten -- not to mention all of the business cards she gave me were gone (always a good sign). And trust me, I learned that Russians are very skeptical of "their" food. I can't rave enough about Red Tavern and Irina. I can't wait to actually eat in the restaurant.
author: Joan S.

description: The borsch soup was the best borsch soup I've ever had in my life. So fresh and extremely tasty. Perfectly red and perfect cuts of beets. We also had beef stroganoff which was heavenly. It came in it's own little pot pie and was also extremely fresh. I had it with buckwheat which was also amazingly made. Then we had the dumplings pelmeni which was also fresh and delicious!! Everything was just wonderful and I'm from Los Angeles and had Russian food there and thought this place was superb. I also enjoyed the atmosphere of the restaurant with the red cloths and overall cleanliness. Super pleased !
author: Lovely E.

description:
I've been wanting to write this review for quite a long time. It's been probably a month since we had a dinner here but my burning desire to put a review down have not left me still- so here it is. 
I honestly think it was the best Russian food I had in San Francisco so far. Better than Katya's, Cinderella, Fandorin or Red Tavern horrifying precursor Sadko.  
Why 3 stars? Because it's very unbalanced. Our waitress started off really well- she was smily, very attentive and enthusiastic- and that along is a great achievement if you know how Russian servers roll. It all began falling apart when we ordered bottle of Georgian wine- she brought it out being all fancy, with a white cloth, -explained grape and vintage etc, opened a bottle... and just put it next to Mr.  I mean, why to bother starting all strong with all the explanation if you are not planning to pour a taste?.. or ok, if no taste, -just pour it in my damn glass! There is wine etiquette for God sake. You either follow the rules or not. I actually wouldn't mind her bringing it out and putting in front of me in a pure silence. 
...i don't know why I am making such a big deal out of this wine situation, it just felt very odd, abrupt and amusing. 
Then restaurant got filled super fast and she never stopped by ever again.  
However- food was great. Borsch was hearty, polenta was creamy and huge, plov was well seasoned and super greasy (the way its supposed to be),  my only disappointment was stuffed cabbage- it was cold. They obviously microwaved it but center did not get heated. Too bad since it had great potential and i still ate it all. (Noone bothered to ask how we were doing anyway.)  
The best part of whole experience was people watching. Table next to us had very eclectic group of 3- Asian man straight from his home country, clearly on a business trip, Russian lady and Hispanic lady (both looked pretty raunchy). You could tell they all just met and it was awkward for them to hang out.....
 I feel that this is how most Russian places are- they either ignore you entire time and act like you owe them something or give you super cheesy sugar coated service. No middle ground. You just have to take it and roll with it. 
Still haven't decided do I love this restaurant or its gross.
author: Liza B.

description: The entire experience was pretty odd. The waiter approached our table with order pad in hand and didn't introduce himself or say hello. The zucchini pancakes were obviously reheated in the microwave. The Uzbek rice pilaf was greasy (although the lamb was tender and well seasoned) and the  sour cabbage salad had little flavor. It didn't help that there was a screaming little kid still there at 9:30 PM.
author: Brad C.

description: Our original choice closed unexpectedly, but they were kind enough to direct us to the Red Tavern.  We were thrilled with the wonderful food and service.  The stroganoff was divine.
author: Richard M.

description:
Siberian Style Peimeni here is yummy.
Tried beef tongue, bit on the dry side, not juicy enough and flavor is blend.
Nothing too special about this place.
author: S B.

description:
I went to this restuarant with a friend while visiting San Francisco.  The food was good and the service was slow but good.  My friend said she liked her food, but that it was not that impressive.
I also have a problem with a Russian tavern not serving vodka.
author: Richard L.

description: The food and service were nice. However, they had ran out  of many dishes in the menu, which diminished the whole experience.
author: Ezequiel C.

description:
Came in for a birthday celebration with a few friends on a Friday night, after making reservations ahead of time.

To cover the main points:
- food was very good
- service was very friendly
